captions.text:
McLaren's goal for the P1 is simple:
to be the best driver's car in the world on

road and track. To that end we have
a carbon fiber chassis, active suspension

and aerodynamics and power from a V8 that's
assisted by 2 turbos and an electric motor.

In use are the most advanced technologies
from McLaren. Many of which are inspired by
its Formula-1 efftorts. The combined horsepower is 904. Cost: $1,000,000. And all 375 examples

have been sold. Our brief opportunity to drive
the P1 took place at a damp, empty airport in
England that you might recognize from a popular British TV show. So here we are behind the
wheel of a prototype version of a 904 horsepower, one million dollar hypercar on an unfamiliar

track with just a handful of laps to drive.
Let's go.

Alright so this week on Ignition we find out
what it's like to do 3 laps in a McLaren P1
The acceleration is phenomenal
but we know that already it has 900 horsepower or thereabouts.

The sound is ridiculous as
the acceleration.
And the car is just, it's the experience is overwhelming.

We're in race mode we have
traction control off it's a little greasy

it's a little wet so things are a little slippery
but this is what it's like to do a British car test of a British car.
This corner's a lot of fun.
The level of acceleration, the level of deceleration, the level of G-forces altogether
are other worldly I mean it's insane.
The car is stiff in race mode it's very stiff but the front end feels light and easy to direct.
The stability control is helping out quite a bit even in race mode
helping the breaks you can feel them working a little bit

to dial you in but it's only
when you need some help it seems.
It's not extremely forgiving but surprisingly easy to drive. It's tough to focus and talk and
think and drive fast at the same time.
Let's not forget the car generating this overwhelming power is a plug-in hybrid
that isn't penalized by a gas guzzler tax. Hit the E-mode button

and the engine turns off. From there you have
around 6 miles of range and acceleration like

a Civi Si. That of course isn't the point
of the car.
When the engine is on the motor acts like

a 177 horsepower power app and recharges
when you're at partial throttle and when you lift.

It's like a boost in video games refilling
after each lap. Power isn't the center point

though it's the sophistication in the aerodynamics
and chassis the body work is aggressive not

very pretty and that's because aside from
a few design flourishes it's designed around air flow.

A massive wing and 2 underbody flaps
continually adjust depending on what the car's doing:

Adding drag to help braking or reducing
it to bring top end speed. In race mode the right

height drops 2 inches and the wing raises
nearly a foot higher. The result is 1323 pounds

of downforce at 160 miles per hour. You
can only describe the P1's monumental acceleration

in so many ways but I wanted to find out just
how fast it was. So when no one was looking

I grabbed our data acquisition hard ware,
took the car down the runway out of view and

hit the launch control button. Presenting a world
exclusive acceleration run in the McLaren P1.

At 9.8 seconds to the quarter mile the P1
is the quickest production car tested
in Motortrend's 65 year history.

I'm going to go around 1
more time because screw the rules.

How can you not enjoy that how can you not enjoy power
sliding this car?

That's a fantastic achievement in itself but then you start realizing that
there's more that it's passed all the safety

tests that it isn't penalized by a gas tax,
that it can run briefly as a zero emissions electric car.

And then there's lateral limits.
In my brief time there the trouble wasn't with driving it

but comprehending what was
happening. WIth the P1 you simply have to

forget what you know about the capabilities
of modern performance cars. The P1 changes everything.

We've reached a new threshold,
a new level, a new performance benchmark we've

reached this new echelon of car this new area
and it's wild.
It is absolutely wild. Is it too much? It starts to beg the question is it too much?

title: 2014 McLaren P1: The World's Quickest Production Car! - Ignition Ep. 108
